results.title: Time exposure: William Henry Jackson picture maker of the old West
results.creator_credit: Richard Hoffman III, Tom Hubbard and Crystal Productions
results.brief_description: Portrays the development and history of the American West during the last half of the nineteenth century as seen through the photography of William Henry Jackson, pioneer photagrapher of the West. Emphasizes the effect of Jackson’s photography on the preservation of national parks. Jackson, who started working at a photographic studio at the age of fifteen, was also involved in recording the daily camp life during the Civil War. He worked his way to California on a wagon train, arriving in Los Angeles when it was a town of 5,000 people, where he eventually setup his own photographic studio. Includes a demonstration of wet plate photographic process. Narrated by Burgess Meredith and Lowell Thomas. Writen by Kay Eldridge. original music by MAry Martin.

results.title: Time before, time now = Taem bifo, taem nao
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In the first eight days in December, 1979, over 2000 people from all over the New Hebrides travelled to Vila, the capital, to take part in the first National Arts Festival, covering a wide range of cultural activities. The Festival was arranged to help foster interest in the ‘old ways’ and try to unite the people through their rich culture. Pidgin dialogue, subtitled in English.

results.title: Time and terrain: a study in Canadian geology
results.creator_credit: Colin Low, Jim MacKay and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: In this study in Canadian geology, the animation artist uses strange cone shapes to represent the volcanoes once covering much of Canada until they crumbled before age-long attacks of rain and wind. A pattern of rivers shows how silt was carried to the ocean until, after eons had passed, the land sank entirely under water except for a stubborn island, the Canadian Shield. Mood music increases the primordial atmosphere of the film, as layers of silt turn to layers of rock under the sea and violent pressures squeeze them suddenly upward to form jagged mountains, striped with twisted and tilted strata. The Ice Age follows. When it has passed, we see the birth of Canada’s lakes and rivers. Even today the terrain is subtly altering, as the Earth obeys Nature’s one fixed law - perpetual change. Photography by Lyle Enright. Animation by Colin Low. Music by Robert Fleming. Voice and Narration by Robert Christie.

results.title: Time's Up
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Connop, Daniela Torsh and Film Australia Women's Film Unit
results.brief_description: A history of the campaign for equal pay for women in Australia. The film focuses on the ACTU test case, using the nursing profession, for equal pay for work of “comparable value”. It features ACTU unionist, Jenny Acton, nurse, Alex Anderson, and feminist Zelda D’Aprano who created news in Melbourne in 1972 by chaining herself to the door of the Commonwealth Government offices as a protest against unequal pay rates. A combination of interviews and archival footage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cynthia Connop, Daniela Torsh and Film Australia Women’s Film Unit

results.title: Timboon Consolidated School
results.creator_credit: E.J. Perry and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Makes an argument for the consolidation of local small rural schools into large purpose built centralised establishments with a post-primary school element. Presents the organisational elements involved: bussing, staffing, design, curriculum etc.

results.title: Tim Roth: made in Britain
results.creator_credit: Damon Thomas, Emily Fielden and BBC
results.brief_description: Profiling British actor Tim Roth who has worked extensively in Hollywood (Reservoir dogs, Pulp fiction, Planet of the apes), this documentary was filmed in 1999, when Roth, tired of the actor’s lot, was directing and promoting his directorial debut “The War zone”. In interview Roth discusses his influences, experiences both as a fledgling actor and successful star, fame, his upbringing, hopes for the future, feelings about his craft and desire to retire from acting and pursue directing. As a young thespian Roth started off in theatre before landing a key role in “Made in Britain”, a controversial TV movie about juvenile delinquency, which enabled Roth to forge ahead with a successful film career. Roth was subsequently cast in “Jumpin’ at the Boneyard” (1992) which led to a key role in “Reservoir dogs” (1992), Quentin Tarantino’s ultra-violent heist film that made several unknown actors famous. Also interviewed are school friends, colleagues, fellow actors Ray Winstone, Gary Oldman, Chris Penn and John Hurt, Mike Leigh who directed Roth in “Meantime” (1981), and Tom Stoppard director and writer of “Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead” (1990). Features extensive footage of Tim Roth shooting “The War zone” using inexperienced actors and shows Roth dealing with the mixed critical reception that his film received in the UK.
